candidates.title: automerge-wasm: Pin version of wasm-bindgen
candidates.body:
Problem: The wasm-bindgen dependency of automerge-wasm has to be exactly the same as the version of the CLI used to build the JavaScript package. The CI environment is pinned to a specific version in the Github actions workflow but the version of wasm-bindgen in the Cargo.toml file is not.  This means that when a new version of wasm-bindgen is released, the build fails because cargo automatically pulls the latest version of wasm-bindgen which is different to the version used in the CI environment.

Solution: Pin the version of wasm-bindgen in the Cargo.toml to the same version as in CI.

candidates.title: Prevents coupling UTF-16 text encoding to WASM targets
candidates.body:
### Related PRs
   - https://github.com/automerge/automerge/pull/597
   - https://github.com/automerge/automerge/pull/641
   - https://github.com/automerge/automerge/pull/626

### Description
We've encountered several issues with the `Splice Text`, `Cursor`, and `Marks` operations in the automerge-swift project. The root cause is that in cross-platform projects, WASM systems are not guaranteed to use UTF-16 text encoding. For example, in [automerge-swift](https://github.com/automerge/automerge-swift) the default encoding is Unicode Scalar, which is also used in the public API. This leads to **text width** misalignments when sharing code with other WASM systems.

I guess UTF-16 was initially enforced in WASM because of its design with JavaScript in mind, but text encoding can vary depending on the platform. This PR relaxes that constraint by introducing a compile-time flag (`utf16-indexing`). By default, the WASM target will still be compiled with UTF-16 indexing to ensure backward compatibility with existing projects, but this can be overridden if clients need it.

side note: PR enables to change WASM Text encoder without changing the current behaviour.

### QA
The original set of tests continues to pass, ensuring backward compatibility with existing projects. [That test](https://github.com/automerge/automerge/blob/890e2eefbcc84365dcb49a4701a28980b5da5e2a/rust/automerge-wasm/test/test.mts#L2016) confirms that the original UTF-16 functionality remains intact.

candidates.title: Cargo deny updates
candidates.body:
Various updates to move to the latest version of `cargo-deny`:

* Update `cbindgen` and `itertools` to remove duplicate dependencies in our depenency tree
* Switch from depending on `json` to `jzon` in the `edit-trace` crate as `json` is no longer maintained
* Modify the deny.toml config to remove deprecated keys

candidates.title: Fix corruption bug
candidates.body:
Context: when we save a document we encode all the actor IDs in the
document at the start of the encoded document and then refer to those
actor IDs by their index into the encoded array. Similarly, in the
runtime representation of ops we don't directly store the actor ID but
instead refer to an index into a table of actor IDs held elsewhere. This
means that when we write the document to storage we need to translate
from the runtime indexes to the stored indexes.

Problem: in some cases we were creating actor indexes in the runtime
table of actors which we never wrote to the document. This meant that
the runtime actor indexes could get out of sync with the actors we write
to the document. This resulted in the actor indexes being wrong when
loading the document and consequently in "missing actor ID" errors.

Solution: when encoding actor IDs don't use the runtime table as a
translation table directly. Instead build a new table which contains
only the actor IDs we know we are writing.

Fixes #897 #919

candidates.title: rust: Upgrade `itertools` dependency to `0.12`
candidates.body: It seems all uses in this library are still compatible.  The `0.10.5` release is over a year old and `0.11` about 7 months old, and we'd like to get rid of some duplicate dependencies in our tree.

repo.name: automerge
repo.description: A JSON-like data structure (a CRDT) that can be modified concurrently by different users, and merged again automatically.
